This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night
The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information
learning.explanation: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration. This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night. The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information. The quality of information is dependent on the accuracy of the initial (input) data, and the precision with which the system aligns to True North. For navigation in a horizontal plane, two accelerometers are needed, which are normally aligned with True North and True East. To keep the reference valid, the accelerometers are mounted on a gyro-stabilised platform, which maintains the correct orientation during all aeroplane manoeuvres. Rate integrating gyros are for use as sensors to detect any departure of the platform from its level and desired alignment. BOUNDED ERRORS These errors build up to a maximum positive and negative values, and return to zero within each 84.4 minutes Schuler cycle and thus averages out over the period. The main causes of these errors are: - platform tilt, due to initial misalignment - inaccurate measurement of acceleration by accelerometers - integrator errors in the first integration stage UNBOUNDED ERRORS - CUMULATIVE TRACK ERRORS These errors arise from the misalignment of the accelerometers in the horizontal plane, and the main causes of these errors are: - Initial azimuth misalignment of the platform. - Wander of the azimuth gyro. UNBOUNDED ERRORS - CUMULATIVE DISTANCE ERROR These errors give rise to cumulative errors in the recording of the total distance travelled. The main causes of this error are: - Wander in the levelling gyros. - Integrator errors in the second stage of integration. INHERENT ERRORS The irregular shape and composition of the Earth, together with the movement of the Earth through space, and other factors provide further possible sources of error. Such errors vary from system to system, depending upon the balance achieved between accuracy on one hand and the simplicity of design, reliability, ease of construction and cost of production on the other.

key_points: The Inertial Reference System (IRS) receives data from three internal Ring Laser gyros (RLGs), and three internal accelerometers, measuring accelerations on all three aircraft’s body axes (longitudinal, lateral, and normal)

learning.explanation: The Inertial Reference System (IRS) receives data from three internal Ring Laser gyros (RLGs), and three internal accelerometers, measuring accelerations on all three aircraft’s body axes (longitudinal, lateral, and normal). Other data is also required, such as the: TAS - to calculate the wind speed/direction. Initial position – because actual aircraft position at any point during the flight, is calculated from the distance and direction flown from the initial reference position entered in the system. Barometric altitude – to stabilize the vertical navigation, thus stabilizing vertical velocity and inertial altitude information. The platform can output the inertial height by itself, but its accuracy is insufficient for precise height control, hence the barometric altitude input. The initial alignment and leveling of the IRS need to be carried out when the aircraft is stationary and on the ground. A set of three accelerometers will sense gravitational acceleration that will derive the local vertical of the platform. Once the vertical is found thanks to the gravity, any change of attitude in space will be detected, but they will only come from the Earth’s rotation (on the ground when stationary). Moreover, by detecting the drift due to the earth’s rotation, the Inertial Reference Unit (IRU) will be able to internally calculate the True North. Latitude can also be internally calculated, but because this calculation is not sufficiently precise, a manual position input is required from the flight crew for this alignment sequence. Therefore, the system will compare the inserted latitude with the calculated one and compute precisely the aircraft’s position. On the other hand, the IRS cannot calculate/measure longitude, therefore the only reference is the one provided by the pilot during the alignment process.

If you do have any further exam feedback, please let us know in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions
com, thank you! Inertial Navigation Systems are devices which allow us to have a self contained method of navigating, via just the accelerations of the aircraft
learning.explanation: Note: Obviously the wording is not very specific in this question, and we could use any further feedback for clarification on what EASA are asking. If you do have any further exam feedback, please let us know in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! Inertial Navigation Systems are devices which allow us to have a self contained method of navigating, via just the accelerations of the aircraft. The basic principle is that, if an INS knows the initial location of the aircraft, and knows that it is completely still at that time (during initialisation), then it can precisely measure the aircraft's turns and accelerations to calculate its current position. It uses the mathematical process of integration to first work out the aircraft's velocity and direction, then integrates again to find the change in distance, which it then adds/removes from the original location. The oldest INSs use a "stable platform" design, which is a large platform that is kept pointing towards True North and perfectly upright, no matter the aircraft's heading or attitude. It manages this by using 3 rate-integrating gyros to measure the aircraft's turns around all three axes, and counter them by moving the platform the other way. It can then use 2 accelerometers to calculate the North-South acceleration, and the East-West accelerations, which are fed into a mechanical computer (a complex set of cogs and gears) that provide an output of speed and position, and other useful metrics. More modern aircraft use Inertial Reference Systems (IRSs), which are a form of INS, but are connected directly to the aircraft (no stable platform). These are much lighter, and less complex to have on board, as they use a set of 3 ring laser gyroscopes and 3 accelerometers to measure all the rotations and accelerations, and then calculates into their various components (North-South, East-West and Vertical) using modern computer methods. This is called a strapdown system, as it is fixed to the aircraft, and is much more usable with other systems, as it can feed info to the FMS, etc. This question is not very well worded, as the question is asking about inertial navigation systems, but the most correct answer (and the answer from feedback) is actually more related to IRSs. To clarify, we can go through each option: "true airspeed (TAS) on the x, y and z axes." This is quite blatantly wrong, airspeed is measured in one axis by the pitot tubes. "indicated Airspeed (IAS) on the x, y and z axes." Same as above, still wrong. "acceleration along the aircraft's pitch, roll and yaw axes." This one is nearly correct, as it does sense accelerations, but not necessarily along these axes (and these axes refer to rotations). INSs sense accelerations in the North-South and East-West directions (and maybe vertically). "acceleration along the north-south, east-west and vertical axes." This is most correct, but only just. As mentioned above, INSs sense accelerations in the North-South and East-West directions. They can sense vertical accelerations also, if they have a third accelerometer, but this is not so well documented in the learning objectives, and is more to do with IRSs, which all measure vertical acceleration as part of their normal process. This is why this question can garner some opposing views, depending on interpretation. So far, this is our best option.

key_points: In the event of a failure of one of the autopilots, or if they deliver different control command outputs, the automatic landing system can behave in either of two ways: fail passive or fail operational

Fail passive - The automatic landing system is fed by only two fail-safe autopilots comparing their computations, therefore it cannot determine which one of the units is delivering the correct steering commands
In the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, but the landing is not completed automatically
learning.explanation: In the event of a failure of one of the autopilots, or if they deliver different control command outputs, the automatic landing system can behave in either of two ways: fail passive or fail operational. Fail passive - The automatic landing system is fed by only two fail-safe autopilots comparing their computations, therefore it cannot determine which one of the units is delivering the correct steering commands. In the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail operational - The automatic landing system consists of three independent autopilot channels per controlled axis, it is capable of determining the failed component and excluding it from the computation. In the event of a failure, the approach, flare, and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system.

For example, when the pilot engages the CWS of a conventional autopilot and carries out a maneuver in roll when the control wheel is released, the autopilot will maintain the flight attitude obtained at that moment.

content.question: You are the pilot of an aircraft, manually flying using the Flight Directors (FD). When both the FD bars cross in the centre of the aircraft symbol, it means that...

options.A: both the pitch and yaw attitudes of your aircraft are equal to zero.
options.B: both the pitch and roll attitudes of your aircraft are equal to zero.
options.C: your aircraft is in the optimum attitude computed for the planned flight path.
options.D: your aircraft maintains the optimum altitude and heading.

key_points: In a Flight Director System (FDS), pitch and roll commands compute to achieve or maintain a particular condition of flight
The commands from the Flight Director computer are also modelled so that any command given will not unduly over stress the airframe
For example, in Heading Mode the Flight Directors will indicate a fly to command to bring the aircraft on to the desired heading
learning.explanation: In a Flight Director System (FDS), pitch and roll commands compute to achieve or maintain a particular condition of flight. The commands from the Flight Director computer are also modelled so that any command given will not unduly over stress the airframe. For example, in Heading Mode the Flight Directors will indicate a fly to command to bring the aircraft on to the desired heading. Movement of the roll command bar to the left or right requires rolling the aeroplane to the left or right, in order to centre the command bar, and to satisfy the computed command. When centred, the command bar indicates the achievement of the required pitch attitude. By virtue of the fact that the command bar deflections are the resultant of a combination of system inputs, do not regard them as positional to acquire a required state. They are simply a command for change in pitch and/or roll attitude, e.g. - Pitch Command Bar UP - Pitch Up - Roll Command Bar RIGHT - Roll Right Pitch Command Bar UP - Pitch Up

content.question: When engaged, the autopilot manoeuvres the aeroplane in accordance within a set of control laws. The purpose of these control laws is to…

options.A: ensure any movement of the control surface(s) is smooth and accurate for improved passenger comfort.
options.B: prevent the ability to by-pass the computers or the standby systems to operate without the computers.
options.C: prevent unacceptable loads on the aeroplane or prevent hazardous deviations from the flight path.
options.D: prevent the aeroplane from deviating from its desired flight path by an amount exceeding the limits established by the operator.

key_points: AUTO PILOT CONTROL LAWS The autopilot must be able to manoeuvre the aircraft logically and safely in a similar manner to the way a human pilot should
This means ensuring the autopilot does not break aircraft limitations in terms of speed, load factor, pitch and bank limits etc
The autopilot should be able to use a satisfactory amount of the performance of the aircraft otherwise the manoeuvres would take too long to execute
learning.explanation: AUTO PILOT CONTROL LAWS The autopilot must be able to manoeuvre the aircraft logically and safely in a similar manner to the way a human pilot should. This means ensuring the autopilot does not break aircraft limitations in terms of speed, load factor, pitch and bank limits etc. The autopilot should be able to use a satisfactory amount of the performance of the aircraft otherwise the manoeuvres would take too long to execute. Whenever the autopilot is required to make a correction either for stability or when referring to a particular flight path, the control response will always be in proportion to deviation or corrective action required but only up to a limit that prevents the autopilot attempting a manoeuvre that would cause an excursion from the safe flight envelope. Command Speed Limiting The AFS provides speed, pitch and thrust commands to avoid exceeding the following limit speeds: - VMO/MMO. - Wing flap limiting speeds. - Landing gear speeds. - Minimum speed. Reversion Modes During some flight situations, speed control by the AFDS or A/T alone could be insufficient to prevent exceeding a limit speed. If this occurs, AFDS and A/T mode automatically revert to a more effective combination. The reversion modes are: - Placard Limit reversion. - Minimum airspeed reversion. Mode reversion occurs slightly before reaching the limit speed. Flight Envelope Protection Flight envelope protection is installed with the aim of ensuring that the aircraft remains within the normal flight envelope in all phases of flight The system provides protection in all phases of flight to prevent the aircraft exceeding the limits for the following parameters: - Angle of Attack - Speed - Pitch attitude - Bank angle - Loadfactor

content.question: The crew of a multi-pilot aircraft are performing an approach, with the autopilot (AP) coupled to the ILS. They notice the AP system making large corrections in pitch close to the ground, leading to oscillations. The safest course of action for the crew is to…

options.A: Disconnect the AP and continue flying manually.
options.B: Disconnect the AP and perform a go-around.
options.C: Conduct a go-around with the AP engaged.
options.D: Reduce thrust with the AP engaged.

key_points: The safest course of action for the crew when they notice the autopilot (AP) making large pitch corrections close to the ground, leading to oscillations is to disconnect the AP and perform a go-around
Timely manual intervention is crucial as a way of mitigating loss of control

As it is unclear how close the aircraft is to the ground or the severity of deviation, disconnecting the AP and continuing to fly manually in this situation can be hazardous and may result in an unstable approach or even loss of control
learning.explanation: The safest course of action for the crew when they notice the autopilot (AP) making large pitch corrections close to the ground, leading to oscillations is to disconnect the AP and perform a go-around. Timely manual intervention is crucial as a way of mitigating loss of control. As it is unclear how close the aircraft is to the ground or the severity of deviation, disconnecting the AP and continuing to fly manually in this situation can be hazardous and may result in an unstable approach or even loss of control. Reducing thrust with the AP engaged is unlikely to resolve the issue and may even worsen the situation. Conducting a go-around with the AP engaged can be risky as well, as the system may continue to make large pitch corrections and exacerbate the oscillations. Furthermore, a automatic go-around is only possible when the aircraft is set for a dual channel approach (both AP engaged).

content.question:
The automatic synchronisation function of an autopilot control system:
1 – operates only when the autopilot is engaged
2 – prevents the aircraft's control system from jerking when disengaging the autopilot
3 – prevents the aircraft's control system from jerking when engaging the autopilot
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: The automatic pitch trim is used to: ensure the airplane is properly trimmed when the autopilot is disengaged
permits the elevator to always be in neutral position with respect to the horizontal stabilizer
In other words, it off-loads any steady-state elevator deflection
learning.explanation: The automatic pitch trim is used to: ensure the airplane is properly trimmed when the autopilot is disengaged. permits the elevator to always be in neutral position with respect to the horizontal stabilizer. In other words, it off-loads any steady-state elevator deflection. When the autopilot is engaged, the role of the automatic pitch trim is to relieve the autopilot servo motor and return the aircraft in-trim when disconnecting the autopilot. It basically provides a smooth ‘HAND-OVER’ when disengaging the autopilot. Caution! Do not confuse the auto trim with the automatic synchronization function which is providing a smooth `TAKE-OVER` when engaging the autopilot. The auto synchronization function will prevent the autopilot engagement it is inoperative, as this might result in an abrupt snatch and jerks of the autopilot during engagement. For an airplane fitted with a mechanical flight control system, the automatic pitch trim system is active whenever the autopilot is engaged. On the other hand, when flying a fly-by-wire aircraft, the automatic pitch trim is always active either you are flying it manually or with the autopilot engaged. When flying an FBW aircraft manually, the system eliminates the need for the pilot to make control column inputs (or manual trim) to compensate for flight path parameter alterations such as thrust changes, landing gear configuration changes, or slats/flaps configuration changes. Summary: `HAND-OVER` - automatic pitch trim function. `TAKE-OVER` - automatic synchronization function.

Control laws instruct the computer how to react to deviation inputs, depending on the actual flight situation
The main goal of control laws is to prevent violations of the aircraft flight envelope and other potentially hazardous situations
learning.explanation: Scientifically: Control laws are the predefined correlation between received input data and generated output data. Control laws instruct the computer how to react to deviation inputs, depending on the actual flight situation. The main goal of control laws is to prevent violations of the aircraft flight envelope and other potentially hazardous situations. In simple words, hand control inputs or mode control panel inputs create a deviation signal. Using control laws, the computer creates an output to the servo actuators to move the control surfaces.

content.question: A pilot is manually flying an ILS approach. The Flight Director roll bar is to the left of centre, but the ILS raw indicator is to the right. What should the pilot do?

options.A: Switch off the Flight Director and follow the raw data. This indication scenario shows an obvious fault in the system.
options.B: Ignore both indicators and revert to visual flight.
options.C: Follow the Flight Director, which is indicating the correct course of action to return to the centreline.
options.D: Initiate an immediate go around.

key_points: The flight directors provide information for the pilot to join a desired path with the optimum attitude
Movement of the roll command bar to the left or right requires rolling the aeroplane to the left or right, in order to centre the command bar, and to satisfy the computed command
When centred, the command bar indicates the achievement of the required attitude
learning.explanation: The flight directors provide information for the pilot to join a desired path with the optimum attitude. Movement of the roll command bar to the left or right requires rolling the aeroplane to the left or right, in order to centre the command bar, and to satisfy the computed command. When centred, the command bar indicates the achievement of the required attitude. The ILS raw indicator indicates the position of the desired track in relation to your position. Therefore, if the indicator indicates a right deviation, it means that the desired track is right of the aircraft. In this case, if the flight director shows a left deflection it means that the aircraft needs a slight correction to the left in order to intercept the desired track in the most efficient way. This would be common, for instance, shortly before reaching the desired radial - the flight director will move left so that the aircraft doesn't overshoot the desired track. However, the ILS raw indicator would still show a right deflection.

Refer to figure.
An example of a typical Multifunction Display (MFD) with AFCS controls and Flight Mode Annunciators (FMAs) is shown in the annex. The pilot will follow the Flight Director's (FD) instructions while manually flying an ILS approach. The guidance from the raw data localizer (LOC) and glideslope (GS) indications shows that the aircraft is established on the ILS. key_points: Let's think about it like this; “There's an ILS approach for a runway that has an FAF where you have to be at 3500 feet
You plan to descend manually and press the APPR button as well for flight director assistance
LOC and GS are armed
learning.explanation: Let's think about it like this; “There's an ILS approach for a runway that has an FAF where you have to be at 3500 feet. You plan to descend manually and press the APPR button as well for flight director assistance. LOC and GS are armed. You continued the flight, frequently checking the DME distance from the runway. When you reached the appropriate distance from the runway, you commenced the descent with the descend rate you calculated before or the GS inoperative descent rate (480 fpm). Although you tracked the final approach course and the GS path, neither the LOC nor the GS was established (If they were established, they would appear in green on the PFD). So Both LOC and GS modes have failed to activate. In addition, since the FD still shows 3500 feet in ALT mode, it does not show appropriate guidance about your planned path (If the GS was established, the flight director would indicate descent). Basic (stabilization) functions: Pitch and bank angle hold (= attitude hold) Vertical speed hold Wings level hold

content.question: While performing an ILS approach, what could be the danger of activating the approach mode (APP) if you are high above the glide path?

options.A: The autopilot might try to capture a false glide path.
options.B: The autopilot could initiate a premature descent and fly into terrain.
options.C: The aircraft's altitude will increase.
options.D: The aircraft may enter an overspeed condition.

key_points: The ILS has two main components: the localizer and the glide slope
The localizer provides lateral guidance for the aircraft, ensuring that it remains aligned with the centerline of the runway
The glide slope provides vertical guidance, indicating the angle at which the aircraft should descend towards the runway
learning.explanation: The ILS has two main components: the localizer and the glide slope. The localizer provides lateral guidance for the aircraft, ensuring that it remains aligned with the centerline of the runway. The glide slope provides vertical guidance, indicating the angle at which the aircraft should descend towards the runway. One of the challenges of the ILS is that it can produce false signals, known as false lobes. False lobes are due to both the weak sidelobes of the original lobes and the reflection of the lower signals off the ground, creating additional, spurious signals that can confuse the aircraft's receiver. False lobes can cause the aircraft to deviate from the correct glide slope or localizer path, potentially leading to an unsafe condition.

content.question: Assuming the autopilot is in heading hold mode, what would happen to the autopilot if the flux valve started drifting in an aircraft equipped with a single flux valve?

options.A: The autopilot would start drifting off too.
options.B: The autopilot would disengage automatically.
options.C: The 'FLUX ERROR' warning light would illuminate on the autopilot control panel, and the autopilot would use its internal logic to compensate for the error.
options.D: Nothing. The autopilot is independent from the flux valve.

key_points: A flux valve consists of two identical bars or spokes of highly permeable (easily magnetised and de-magnetised) material, mounted on a common hub

The detector unit (flux valve) senses the earth’s magnetic field and reproduces it within the compass unit, where it is compared with the position of the gyro drive shaft (which also positions the compass card indicator – the indication of heading to the pilot)
Autopilot Heading Mode The simplest nav mode is to have the aircraft keep flying in the direction you select, this is called Heading Mode
learning.explanation: A flux valve consists of two identical bars or spokes of highly permeable (easily magnetised and de-magnetised) material, mounted on a common hub. The detector unit (flux valve) senses the earth’s magnetic field and reproduces it within the compass unit, where it is compared with the position of the gyro drive shaft (which also positions the compass card indicator – the indication of heading to the pilot). Autopilot Heading Mode The simplest nav mode is to have the aircraft keep flying in the direction you select, this is called Heading Mode. In this mode the pilot selects a desired heading, either using a knob on the HSI, using the central FDS/autopilot panel or on the MCP. The Flight Director roll bar commands the aeroplane to fly to the Pre- Selected Heading, and subsequently to hold that heading. To achieve this, the computer receives inputs from the attitude reference source, the VG, and the course from the compass system. If the heading source is purely magnetic, the Autopilot will follow the heading regarding this source. If is is incorrect, the autopilot will follow an incorrect heading. Having two flux-valves with combined outputs, is used to reduce errors which otherwise may be present in systems using single pendulously mounted magnetic field responsive devices.

content.question: What commands does the flight director issue during take-off mode?

options.A: The pitch mode holds attitude to avoid obstacles and maintain adequate clearance, and the roll mode maintains the runway direction through the LOC.
options.B: The pitch mode holds a constant pitch attitude, and the roll mode maintains the runway direction through the LOC.
options.C: The pitch mode holds a constant pitch attitude to ensure obstacle clearance, and the roll mode maintains the runway direction through the SID.
options.D: The pitch mode commands an attitude to maintain a defined speed above V2 and tracks the runway heading.

key_points: The Flight Director takeoff mode is engaged by pressing either of the TO/GA switches on the throttles
The AFDS annunciation will be TO/GA
During take-off, prior to 60 KIAS, the initial FD commands are for 10° nose-down pitch and wings level
learning.explanation: The Flight Director takeoff mode is engaged by pressing either of the TO/GA switches on the throttles. The AFDS annunciation will be TO/GA. During take-off, prior to 60 KIAS, the initial FD commands are for 10° nose-down pitch and wings level. At 60 kt IAS, the FD command changes to 15° nose-up and wings level. At lift-off, the pitch command continues at 15° nose-up until sufficient climb rate is acquired. Pitch then commands MCP speed (normally V2) plus 20 knots. This speed is calculated and set during the pre-flight checks. The roll command maintains HDG SEL - the roll mode keeps the aircraft aligned with the runway heading. Next, when either autopilot is engaged or when the MCP speed selector is rotated, 20 kt IAS is added automatically to the MCP IAS display.

content.question:
The flight guidance system has different modes. Considering the autopilot/flight director, which of the following describes one feature of the go-around mode?
When selected, the go-around mode engages and the aeroplane climbs...

options.A: only if the aeroplane is below the selected missed approach altitude and following an ILS.
options.B: when it is approaching the missed approach point or minimum descent altitude for the approach.
options.C: whether it is below or above the selected missed approach altitude at the point of initiation.
options.D: only if the selected missed approach altitude is above the aeroplane at the point of initiation.

learning.explanation: 022.06.02.01.08: Explain the following mixed modes: take-off and go-around (TOGA); approach (APP). The Go-around mode is one of the three mixed modes mentioned in the EASA LOs above, with the other two being take-off and approach modes. All three of these modes interact with the autothrottle and autopilot systems to achieve the desired outcomes. When the A/T ARM switch is turned on, the A/T go-around mode becomes active below 2000 feet RA, whether or not the AFDS is engaged. Once activated, the A/T go-around mode remains available for engagement until 2 seconds after touchdown. To engage this mode, you simply press the TOGA switch. When engaged, "GA" is displayed for the A/T, and the thrust levers move to the reduced go-around thrust setting, resulting in a climb rate of 1000 to 2000 feet per minute. Pressing the TOGA switch a second time causes the A/T to advance the thrust to the full go-around N1 limit. On Boeing aircraft, this entails pressing TOGA, while on Airbus planes, it involves moving the throttles into the TOGA detent. In either case, the engines power up to full thrust, and the autopilot disengages the approach mode, allowing the aircraft to climb away from the ground. It's important to note that the Go-around mode is not constrained by specific altitudes or heights. Therefore, if the pilot initiates a go-around, the aircraft will climb regardless of whether it is below or above the pre-selected missed approach altitude.

content.question: During an automatic landing, between 50 ft AGL and touch down, the autopilot maintains…

options.A: a vertical speed depending on the GPS height.
options.B: a constant flight path angle with reference to the ground.
options.C: a constant vertical speed.
options.D: a vertical speed depending on the radio altimeter height.

key_points: For an A320 or B737, a standard VS at a standard glide path angle and aircraft weight is between 700 and 800 ft/min
As you can imagine if the aircraft keeps this rate of descent until touch down, it will do nothing but making a hole into the runway
Therefore, the autopilot system needs some inputs to flare the aircraft and achieve a smooth touch down
learning.explanation: For an A320 or B737, a standard VS at a standard glide path angle and aircraft weight is between 700 and 800 ft/min. As you can imagine if the aircraft keeps this rate of descent until touch down, it will do nothing but making a hole into the runway. Therefore, the autopilot system needs some inputs to flare the aircraft and achieve a smooth touch down. These inputs are the radio height, the wind speed/direction, etc. At 50 ft AGL the glideslope signal is disconnected, and between 50 ft AGL and touch down, the autopilot will keep a vertical speed depending on the radio altimeter height, as this is more precise than the barometric altitude. The higher the VS the sooner the aircraft will start to flare.

key_points: Category IIIA (CAT IIIA) operation means a precision instrument approach and landing operation using ILS or MLS with: - DH lower than 100 ft; - RVR not less than 200 m; Note: Automatic landing is not directly connected to CAT III
An automatic landing system is only an equipment providing automatic control of the aircraft during the approach and landing and is not related to particular weather conditions

Fail-passive automatic landing system An automatic landing system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically
learning.explanation: Category IIIA (CAT IIIA) operation means a precision instrument approach and landing operation using ILS or MLS with: - DH lower than 100 ft; - RVR not less than 200 m; Note: Automatic landing is not directly connected to CAT III. An automatic landing system is only an equipment providing automatic control of the aircraft during the approach and landing and is not related to particular weather conditions. Fail-passive automatic landing system An automatic landing system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail passive means in case of a failure of any part of the system the autoland system will turn itself off and the crew has to take over. An example of an autoland sequence: - Approach (APP) mode armed - Localizer and Glide Slope Armed - Localizer Capture - Glide Slope Capture - 400 - 330 feet RA: If FLARE is armed by approximately 350 ft RA, both A/Ps automatically disengage. - At 45 feet Gear Altitude (GA)/50 ft RA: The FLARE mode is automatically engaged - Roll-out In case visual references at the moment of an abnormal occurrence (such as 'NO FLARE' indication) are sufficient and flying conditions such that a visual manual landing can be safely performed, continuation of the approach remains always an option and a crew decision.

Capture phase The aircraft will follow a predefined rate of change of trajectory to achieve the new parameter without overshooting/undershooting. VERTICAL SPEED An aircraft's vertical speed is the positive or negative rate of altitude change with respect to time. This is usually expressed in feet per minute (ft/min). The Vertical Speed in an aircraft is indicated with a vertical speed indicator (VSI) or instantaneous vertical speed indicator (IVSI). FLIGHT PATH ANGLE The Flight Path Angle is the angle between the Aircraft’s Velocity Vector and the Horizon. If you are flying in a level flight your Flight Path Angle will be zero (over the horizon), regardless of the Pitch Angle. During a descent, the Flight Path Angle will be negative (below the horizon) thus when climbing the Flight Path Angle will be positive (over the horizon). FLIGHT PATH VECTOR The circular symbol represents the aircraft's axis in relation to the vertical and lateral movement referenced to the Earth's surface. If you were stationary on the ground, the circle would be on the horizon line and centred in the display. The data received by the FPV is derived mostly from the Internal Reference System (IRS) of the aircraft; therefore, the Flight Path Vector provides an almost instantaneous display of flight path angle and drift information.

content.question: The pilot sets the autobrake to MAX due to fear of exceeding runway distance. The pilot will…

options.A: Not use reverse thrust.
options.B: Expect the autobrake system to apply necessary braking to stay on the runway.
options.C: Expect the autobrake system to apply maximum braking effort.
options.D: Expect the autobrake system to modulate braking pressure to maintain given rate.

key_points: Learning Objectives 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objectives 021.04.03.04.04: Describe how an autobrake system setting will either apply maximum braking (RTO or MAX) or result in a given rate of deceleration, where the amount of braking applied may be affected by: the use of reverse thrust; slippery runway. While this question may be type-specific, the learning objectives offer limited room for discussion as you can read above. Automatic Braking (Autobrake) systems offer two modes of operation: Landing Mode Rejected Take-Off (RTO) Mode In Landing Mode (1, 2, 3, MAX), calibrated pressure is automatically applied to the brakes upon touchdown, regardless of pilot input. This system adjusts brake pressure to counteract aircraft drag, thrust reversers, and spoilers, maintaining the chosen deceleration level for modes 1, 2 and 3 and maximum braking for MAX. The Rejected Take-Off (RTO) setting instructs the autobrake system to apply full pressure to the wheel brakes, bringing the aircraft to a stop. Activation of RTO mode occurs when a rejected takeoff is initiated by the pilot at a groundspeed exceeding 88 knots. Note: On a Boeing 737, the 1, 2, 3, and MAX deceleration positions control the autobrake system during landing, modulating brake pressure to achieve specified deceleration rates until the aircraft comes to a complete stop. Regarding other options, the use of reverse thrust and autobrake is not mutually exclusive - Flight crews can employ reverse thrust in conjunction with autobrake for maximum deceleration. Although the autobrake system is designed to facilitate a smooth landing rollout and keep the aircraft on the runway, pilots must always conduct calculations to ensure that the aircraft does not exceed the available landing distance.

content.question: What happens if, during an automatic approach and landing, the radio altimeter fails?

options.B: The automatic landing system will be fully operational.
options.C: The automatic braking sequence will be impacted.
options.D: The Glide Slope mode will NOT be operational.

key_points: When performing an automatic landing, a radio altimeter is required because the decision heights below CAT I limits (200 ft) are based on radio height and because the autopilot moves from one mode to another, for example, from FLARE to ROLLOUT, using a variety of inputs, particularly radio height
Should the radio altimeter fail during the autoland procedure, the height indication is removed and replaced by a warning flag
As the individual steps of the automatic landing procedure are triggered by radio heights, this situation requires the aircraft to go around and be landed manually
learning.explanation: When performing an automatic landing, a radio altimeter is required because the decision heights below CAT I limits (200 ft) are based on radio height and because the autopilot moves from one mode to another, for example, from FLARE to ROLLOUT, using a variety of inputs, particularly radio height. Should the radio altimeter fail during the autoland procedure, the height indication is removed and replaced by a warning flag. As the individual steps of the automatic landing procedure are triggered by radio heights, this situation requires the aircraft to go around and be landed manually. As for the incorrect options: Glideslope relies upon the ILS and not the radio altimeter. The autobrake relies on weight-on-wheels, throttles retarded and wheels spun up to speed. The autoland will not be fully operational.

Fail-operational Automatic Landing System: An automatic landing system is fail-operational if, in the event of a failure, the approach, flare and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system

A fail-safe is a design feature or practice that in the event of a specific type of failure, inherently responds in a way that will cause minimal or no harm to other equipment, to the environment or to people
learning.explanation: EASA AIR OPS CS-AWO 300 Applicability and Terminology Fail-passive Automatic Landing System: An automatic landing system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail-operational Automatic Landing System: An automatic landing system is fail-operational if, in the event of a failure, the approach, flare and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system. A fail-safe is a design feature or practice that in the event of a specific type of failure, inherently responds in a way that will cause minimal or no harm to other equipment, to the environment or to people. Therefore, we can say that fail-operational is fail-safe.

options.B: Synchronisation is inhibited when the automatic pilot is engaged.
options.C: This system prevents uncommanded surface deflection when the automatic pilot is disengaged.
options.D: It intervenes only when the automatic pilot has been engaged.

key_points: AUTOMATIC SYNCHRONIZATION Before the autopilot is engaged, it must be ensured that the take-over is effected smoothly and without "snatching" of the aircraft's control system
This is achieved by synchronization of aircraft control systems
Autopilot systems synchronization is effected by designed synchronizing circuits
learning.explanation: AUTOMATIC SYNCHRONIZATION Before the autopilot is engaged, it must be ensured that the take-over is effected smoothly and without "snatching" of the aircraft's control system. This is achieved by synchronization of aircraft control systems. Autopilot systems synchronization is effected by designed synchronizing circuits. These synchronizing circuits will automatically sense any existing "standing signals" in the pitch and roll channels and automatically send this data to a synchronizer unit. The synchronizer unit will create equal and opposite attitude signal. Without the synchronizing circuits, the autopilot engagement could cause unwanted and/or violent aircraft manoeuvres. Therefore, it is important to note that, in the event of a synchronizing circuits failure, the autopilot may be prevented from engaging.

key_points: ‘convey air traffic control information to the pilot’ – the FD system is not linked in any way with the information provided by the ATC
‘provide an automatic landing system function’ – the FD is most of the time ON during Autoland, however, it is not the main system allowing the automatic landing
The systems crucial to the Autoland are the autopilot, the radio, altimeter, and the auto-throttle system
learning.explanation: ‘convey air traffic control information to the pilot’ – the FD system is not linked in any way with the information provided by the ATC. ‘provide an automatic landing system function’ – the FD is most of the time ON during Autoland, however, it is not the main system allowing the automatic landing. The systems crucial to the Autoland are the autopilot, the radio, altimeter, and the auto-throttle system. ‘automatically steer the aircraft to waypoints selected on the CDU’ – it is the autopilot’s function to automatically follow the flight plan inserted in the FMS via the CDU. The autopilot can operate without the FDs ON, so this answer option is also incorrect. ‘reduce the pilots' workload by presenting data in the form of control commands’ – the flight directors provide information for the pilot to join a desired path with the optimum attitude. When flying manually, the FD bars indicate the optimum path according to the selected modes, and this ultimately reduces their workload.

SPEED MODE The autothrottle speed mode is activated in cruise and during climb or descent with a prescribed rate. In speed mode, the autothrottle will maintain a preselected airspeed (CAS) or Mach number. The autothrottle will compute and command the new required thrust or power setting to comply with the airspeed selection. key_points: The Flight Guidance (FG) part of the FMGS controls: ‐ The Flight Director (FD) ‐ The Autopilot (AP) ‐ The Autothrust (A/THR)
The AP and FD pitch modes can control a target SPD/MACH or a vertical trajectory, and the A/THR mode can control a fixed thrust or a target SPD/MACH
However, the AP/FD and the A/THR cannot both control a target SPD/MACH simultaneously
learning.explanation: The Flight Guidance (FG) part of the FMGS controls: ‐ The Flight Director (FD) ‐ The Autopilot (AP) ‐ The Autothrust (A/THR). The AP and FD pitch modes can control a target SPD/MACH or a vertical trajectory, and the A/THR mode can control a fixed thrust or a target SPD/MACH. However, the AP/FD and the A/THR cannot both control a target SPD/MACH simultaneously. Therefore the AP/FD pitch modes and A/THR mode are coordinated as follows: ‐ If an AP/FD pitch mode controls a vertical trajectory, the A/THR mode controls the target SPD/MACH. ‐ If an AP/FD pitch mode controls a target SPD or MACH, the A/THR mode controls the thrust. ‐ If no AP/FD pitch mode is engaged, the A/THR mode reverts to controlling the SPD/MACH mode. In other words, the selection of an AP/FD pitch mode determines which mode the A/THR controls. The FMGS has guidance parameters for both AP/FD lateral and vertical modes. The AP/FD lateral modes are the same. Two types of autopilot and flight director modes are available to guide the aircraft: ‐ One that steers the aircraft along the lateral, vertical, and speed profiles according to the data the pilot inserts into the MCDU. Flight Management (in the Flight Management and Guidance Computer) computes the corresponding guidance targets. ‐ The other that steers the aircraft according to target values that the pilot selects and the FCU windows display.

content.question: What can happen if you arm APP mode too early?

options.A: Too early descent.
options.B: Increase altitude.
options.C: False glide path.
options.D: Decrease speed.

key_points: The ICAO envelope for glide slope signal quality ICAO guidelines provide recommendations for ensuring the quality of the ILS glide slope signal
Periodic checks on all ILS equipped runways ensure that the ILS signal quality is at the required level inside a defined envelope
Capturing the ILS glide slope within this envelope ensures that the aircraft is within the area of influence for the primary glide slope
learning.explanation: The ICAO envelope for glide slope signal quality ICAO guidelines provide recommendations for ensuring the quality of the ILS glide slope signal. Periodic checks on all ILS equipped runways ensure that the ILS signal quality is at the required level inside a defined envelope. Capturing the ILS glide slope within this envelope ensures that the aircraft is within the area of influence for the primary glide slope. It also ensures that the ILS signal is of sufficient quality to ensure a normal ILS glide slope capture. The ICAO envelope (fig.4) is within: 10 NM from the runway threshold +/-8° laterally from the runway centerline 0.3 x Θ up to 1.75 x Θ (Θ, being the nominal glide path angle). Make sure the aircraft is in the correct ILS envelope. Arming the approach too soon may cause a false Glide Slope interception out of the protected area, making the airplane descend outside the normal glide slope capture zone. Further information: Secondary glide slopes are an inevitable characteristic due to the ILS antenna design. When an aircraft flies well above the main glide slope, the glide slope deviations displayed on the PFD will refer to the nearest glide slope, which may be a secondary glide slope instead of the primary one. This can lead both the flight crew and the autopilot to erroneously consider the secondary glide slope as the reference for the final descent.

key_points: In the event of a failure of one of the autopilots, or if they deliver different control command outputs, the automatic landing system can behave in either of two ways: fail passive or fail operational

Fail passive - The automatic landing system is fed by only two fail-safe autopilots comparing their computations, therefore it cannot determine which one of the units is delivering the correct steering commands
In the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, but the landing is not completed automatically
learning.explanation: In the event of a failure of one of the autopilots, or if they deliver different control command outputs, the automatic landing system can behave in either of two ways: fail passive or fail operational. Fail passive - The automatic landing system is fed by only two fail-safe autopilots comparing their computations, therefore it cannot determine which one of the units is delivering the correct steering commands. In the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail operational - The automatic landing system consists of three independent autopilot channels per controlled axis, it is capable of determining the failed component and excluding it from the computation. In the event of a failure, the approach, flare, and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system.

content.question: Considering vertical modes of the flight guidance system, when using vertical navigation (VNAV) or managed climb/descent (CLB or DES), the aeroplane should...

options.A: follow the vertical commands computed by the FMS, ensuring the aeroplane follows the flight path regardless of ambient conditions.
options.B: only commence a climb or descent at the position computed by the FMS if a higher/lower (as appropriate) altitude is selected by the pilot first.

key_points: Vertical Navigation (VNAV) VNAV provides vertical profile guidance through the climb, cruise, and descent phases of flight
VNAV controls the path and speed to comply with waypoint crossing restrictions
Waypoint crossing restrictions are entered on the LEGS page waypoint line by pushing the applicable key on the right side of the CDU
learning.explanation: Vertical Navigation (VNAV) VNAV provides vertical profile guidance through the climb, cruise, and descent phases of flight. VNAV controls the path and speed to comply with waypoint crossing restrictions. Waypoint crossing restrictions are entered on the LEGS page waypoint line by pushing the applicable key on the right side of the CDU. Barometric altitude restrictions must be below the cruise altitude to be valid. The speed descent normally begins automatically at the calculated Top of Descent, provided the MCP altitude is reset for the descent. At the T/D, the FMC commands pitch to maintain target descent speed.

The autopiltots and autothrust (autothrottle) functions may be engaged or disengaged
learning.explanation: The Flight Control Unit (FCU), figure 1, or Mode Control Panel (MCP), figure 2, is located on the glare shield and it is the short-term interface between the flight crew and the FMGC. It is used to select any flight parameters or modify those selected in the MCDU (CDU). The autopiltots and autothrust (autothrottle) functions may be engaged or disengaged. Different guidance modes can be selected to change various targets (speed, heading, track, altitude, flight path angle, vertical speed).

content.question: A single element of the autoland system fails. Is it still possible to safely use the autoland function but without the flare mode?

options.A: Yes, as PF is always ready to fly manually and land the plane but only after passing the alert height.
options.B: Yes, the pilot can take over manually for the flare even without visual contact.
options.C: No, the flare mode is required for the complete autoland sequence.
options.D: No, because the rollout mode is frozen at 50 ft.

key_points: Autoland describes a system that fully automates the landing phase of an aircraft's flight, with the human crew supervising the process
Between 50 ft and 40 ft RA, FLARE mode will engage and is completed at touchdown
The FLARE annunciation indicates the second autopilot is fully engaged
learning.explanation: Autoland describes a system that fully automates the landing phase of an aircraft's flight, with the human crew supervising the process. Between 50 ft and 40 ft RA, FLARE mode will engage and is completed at touchdown. The FLARE annunciation indicates the second autopilot is fully engaged. As the lowest weather minimums are directly related to the system status, both pilots must observe the FLARE annunciation. Furthermore, without the flare mode, the aircraft will not be able to land by itself - it will keep the same descent rate down to the threshold. In case the flare mode does not engage, the pilot shall perform a go-around.

Guidance functions – Controlling the movements of the center of gravity in three-dimensional space. These are the different functions of the autopilot that control the path of the aircraft. The guidance functions are provided by the outer loops. Guidance functions: Vertical Navigation Lateral Navigation IAS or Mach number hold Heading hold Altitude hold FMS lateral navigation (LNAV) FMS vertical navigation (VNAV) Localizer intercept and track Glide slope intercept and track VOR radial intercept and hold Flight Path angle hold -------------- Basic (stabilization) functions: Pitch and bank angle hold (= attitude hold) Vertical speed hold Wings level hold

learning.explanation: It is possible to arm a mode, which means that it will automatically be engaged once certain criteria are met. For example, during climb with VS active, another vertical mode such as ALT can be armed. Once the aircraft approaches the newly selected level, VS will be disengaged and replaced by the previous armed ALT mode. "ALT engaged" incorrect ⇒ if you engage ALT, the aircraft will capture the current altitude. The correct sequence would be to engage VS at the desired rate of climb (800 ft/min), arm the altitude 6000 ft so that it captures the desired altitude. VS will then disengage and will be replaced by ALT.

content.question: Which of the following aircraft components are incorporated in an Autoland system?

options.A: Flight controls, hydraulics, and control columns.
options.B: Autopilot(s), autothrust, and control columns.
options.C: Flight controls, hydraulics, and radio altimeter(s).
options.D: Autopilot(s), autothrust, and radio altimeter(s).

key_points: The radio altimeter can be defined as a self-contained on-board aid used to measure the true height of the aircraft
The RA operates between 4200 MHz and 4400 MHz and the maximum range for the indication is typically from the ground up to 2500 ft
Therefore, besides the autopilot (for obvious reasons) it is the primary source of information during an automatic landing
learning.explanation: The radio altimeter can be defined as a self-contained on-board aid used to measure the true height of the aircraft. The RA operates between 4200 MHz and 4400 MHz and the maximum range for the indication is typically from the ground up to 2500 ft. Therefore, besides the autopilot (for obvious reasons) it is the primary source of information during an automatic landing. The transition from one phase to another during the autoland is based on the height measured by the radio altimeter. For example, at 50 ft AGL the glideslope signal is disconnected, and between 50 ft AGL and touch down, the autopilot will keep a vertical speed depending on the radio altimeter height, as this is more precise than the barometric altitude. The higher the VS the sooner the aircraft will start to flare. The auto-thrust is also incorporated in the Autoland system as this provides automatic speed control until touchdown. The pilot will retard the thrust levers at about 10-20 ft (RA) before touchdown.

content.question: Are there any flight envelope protections available in mechanical backup mode?

options.A: Flight envelope protection is provided in mechanical backup mode but with reduced capabilities.
options.B: Yes, flight envelope protection is always provided regardless of the mode.
options.C: No, flight envelope protection is not provided in mechanical backup mode.
options.D: Flight envelope protection is only partially provided in mechanical backup mode.

key_points: Fly-By-Wire aircraft such as the A320 have their Flight Control System divided into Flight Control Laws: Normal Law and reconfiguration laws - Alternate Law, Direct Law and Mechanical Backup
In normal law, the system offers flight envelope protections: - load factor limitation - pitch attitude protection - high-angle-of-attack (AoA) protection - high-speed protection
Depending on the failure, it can lead to a reconfiguration law with reduced or no protections at all
learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire aircraft such as the A320 have their Flight Control System divided into Flight Control Laws: Normal Law and reconfiguration laws - Alternate Law, Direct Law and Mechanical Backup. In normal law, the system offers flight envelope protections: - load factor limitation - pitch attitude protection - high-angle-of-attack (AoA) protection - high-speed protection. Depending on the failure, it can lead to a reconfiguration law with reduced or no protections at all. In the case of Mechanical Back-up, no flight envelope protections are provided. MECHANICAL BACK-UP The purpose of the mechanical backup is to achieve all safety objectives in MMEL dispatch condition: to manage a temporary and total electrical loss, the temporary loss of five fly-by-wire computers, the loss of both elevators, or the total loss of ailerons and spoilers. Pitch - The pilot manually applies trim to the THS to control the aircraft in pitch. Lateral - The pilot uses the rudder pedals as the mechanical backup to laterally control the aircraft.

content.question: The pilot of a modern, large turbojet aeroplane sets the vertical speed mode of the autopilot to carry out a climb. What must he/she be particularly careful of?

options.A: The autopilot may select a rate of climb outside the maximum permissible limit of the aeroplane.
options.B: The engines may overspeed as the autothrottle attempts to maintain airspeed.
options.C: The aeroplane may overspeed in an attempt to maintain the rate of climb.
options.D: If the climb is prolonged, there is a risk that the airspeed may reduce towards the stall.

key_points: Vertical Speed is an autopilot flight guidance vertical mode
In this mode, the Flight Management and Guidance Computer (FMCG) pitch mode guides the aircraft to the target V/S
The corresponding thrust mode is SPEED or MACH
learning.explanation: Vertical Speed is an autopilot flight guidance vertical mode. In this mode, the Flight Management and Guidance Computer (FMCG) pitch mode guides the aircraft to the target V/S. The corresponding thrust mode is SPEED or MACH. The V/S guidance has priority over the speed guidance. If the selected target V/S is too high (relative to the current thrust condition and speed), the FMGC will steer the aircraft to the target V/S, but the aircraft will also accelerate or decelerate. As altitude increases and the air gets thinner, the IAS will reduce for a given pitch setting. Consequently, the angle of attack also reduces. As a result, the vertical speed will reduce for a certain pitch attitude. The autopilot will therefore chase the selected vertical speed by pitching up. This results in further decreased IAS. Ultimately, this could lead to a stall.

content.question: The pilot engages the autopilot and selects Vertical Speed (VS) mode during the climb. If an excessive Vertical Speed is selected, the risk would be…

options.A: An exceedance of the Exhaust Gas Temperature (EGT) limit.
options.B: An uncontrolled loss of airspeed.
options.C: A wrong airspeed indication.
options.D: A level bust.

key_points: The autopilot's vertical speed mode allows you to perform constant-rate climbs and descents
In this mode, the vertical speed is prioritised over airspeed

When you engage the vertical speed mode, the FD/autopilot will attempt to maintain the specified vertical speed until you choose a different setting in autopilot, the aircraft reaches an assigned altitude set into the assigned altitude selector/alerter, or the autopilot is disconnected
learning.explanation: The autopilot's vertical speed mode allows you to perform constant-rate climbs and descents. In this mode, the vertical speed is prioritised over airspeed. When you engage the vertical speed mode, the FD/autopilot will attempt to maintain the specified vertical speed until you choose a different setting in autopilot, the aircraft reaches an assigned altitude set into the assigned altitude selector/alerter, or the autopilot is disconnected. As the power of aircraft is limited at a certain altitude it may not be able to achieve targeted vertical speed. If you command it to climb at a greater FPM rate than your aircraft can perform at that altitude airspeed decays, the autopilot will continually pitch the aircraft up in an attempt to maintain the vertical speed selected. This could happen all the way to the point of stalling.

content.question: When an aircraft, operating in the VOR coupled mode, enters the "cone of confusion" over a VOR station, the roll channel of the autopilot…

options.A: is temporarily disconnected.
options.B: temporarily maintains existing heading.
options.C: remains always coupled to the selected VOR radial.
options.D: is damped by a trim input signal from the lateral trim system.

key_points: Over the ‘cone of confusion’ of a VOR station, the onboard receiver is not able to detect anymore the radial your autopilot was tracking in the VOR mode
As the VOR needle will spin around the autopilot cannot follow and command such instructions
Therefore, the roll channel was designed so that it temporarily maintains the lastly memorized heading before the aircraft entered the ‘con of confusion’
learning.explanation: Over the ‘cone of confusion’ of a VOR station, the onboard receiver is not able to detect anymore the radial your autopilot was tracking in the VOR mode. As the VOR needle will spin around the autopilot cannot follow and command such instructions. Therefore, the roll channel was designed so that it temporarily maintains the lastly memorized heading before the aircraft entered the ‘con of confusion’. After leaving the ‘cone of confusion’, the autopilot will revert back to VOR mode.

content.question: When talking about an engaged autopilot mode, the initial phase is where the...

options.A: attitude is changed to obtain a new trajectory.
options.B: pilot is programming the autopilot on the ground before take-off.
options.C: aircraft maintains a set parameter.
options.D: aircraft is waiting for a certain set of parameters to engage the mode in question.

key_points: The autopilot is capable of producing the same actions as the pilot to maintain aircraft stability in a shorter reaction time
The autopilot is able to: - Sense changes in attitude
- Compute the amount and direction of control required
learning.explanation: The autopilot is capable of producing the same actions as the pilot to maintain aircraft stability in a shorter reaction time. The autopilot is able to: - Sense changes in attitude. - Compute the amount and direction of control required. - Provide the muscle to move the control surfaces using servomotors. - Detect that the control has been applied and that the aircraft has responded. - Return control surfaces back to the neutral condition when the disturbance has been corrected. Before coupling an autopilot with the aircraft’s control system the integrity of the Autopilot Inner Loop must be established to ensure that it may safely take control of the aircraft. AUTOPILOT CONDITIONS OF ENGAGEMENT Before the autopilot can be engaged, certain conditions must be met. These conditions vary with aircraft type. The sequence of events when a mode is engaged and the different phases are as follows: - initial phase: where attitude is changed to obtain a new trajectory in order to achieve the new parameter; the trajectory will be based on rate of closure which is again based on the difference between the original parameter and the new parameter; - capture phase: where the aircraft will follow a predefined rate of change of trajectory to achieve the new parameter without overshooting/undershooting; - tracking or hold phase: where the aircraft will maintain the set parameter until a new change has been initiated.

When we do acquire it, this question will be updated accordingly. Thank you for your understanding! The primary distinction between the Flight Director System (FDS) and the autopilot lies in their operational roles. The FDS exclusively offers control and guidance instructions to either the pilot or the autopilot, whereas the autopilot physically controls the aircraft's surfaces. The FDS, however, serves as a precise means of cross-verifying the control and guidance commands sent to the autopilot. The FDS can be employed in the following ways: • Flight director mode only: In this scenario, the pilot manually operates the flight controls, adhering to the FDS commands. This typically occurs during the final stages of an approach, particularly for non-automated landings. • Autopilot mode only: Here, the pilot provides sensory guidance to the autopilot via the aircraft's control column/stick. This often happens when pilots are using the autopilot in control wheel steering (CWS) mode. • Flight director and autopilot mode: In this mode, the autopilot adjusts the aircraft's control surfaces in response to the steering commands issued by the FDS. This is common during cruising and most other phases of a commercial transport flight. The modes and control panel are the same for both the Flight Director (FD) and the autopilot. The FD will present on the Primary Flight Display (PFD) the instructions that the autopilot is following to meet the preset parameters.

content.question: When can more than one autopilot be engaged at the same time in an aircraft?

options.A: At any time.
options.B: When flying above FL50.
options.C: During autoland.
options.D: Never.

key_points: In order for an aeroplane to carry out a fully automatic approach and landing, it is necessary that the aeroplane be fitted with two or more autopilots, and an autothrottle system

Depending on the number of channels engaged, the system performs an automatic landing with a Land 2 or Land 3 status, which displays on the EADI: Land 2 signifies two autopilot channels engaged giving the system a Fail Passive capability
Land 3 signifies three autopilot channels engaged giving the system a Fail Operational capability
learning.explanation: In order for an aeroplane to carry out a fully automatic approach and landing, it is necessary that the aeroplane be fitted with two or more autopilots, and an autothrottle system. Depending on the number of channels engaged, the system performs an automatic landing with a Land 2 or Land 3 status, which displays on the EADI: Land 2 signifies two autopilot channels engaged giving the system a Fail Passive capability. Land 3 signifies three autopilot channels engaged giving the system a Fail Operational capability. During the cruise and approach to an airport, a single autopilot normally engages and controls the aeroplane along the designated route. As the aeroplane approaches the airport, the flight crew manually selects the other autopilots, and when selecting the APPROACH MODE (APP) on the AFCS control panel, the localiser/glide slope, together with the two remaining autopilots, arm. After setting the localizer frequency and course, pressing the APP switch selects the APP mode. The APP switch illuminates and VOR LOC and G/S armed is annunciated. The APP mode permits selecting the engagement of the second A/P.

learning.explanation: It must be possible for the pilot to disengage the autopilot via Instinctive Cut-Out Buttons, which are located on the control column. These buttons are positioned on the control wheel (sidestick), so the hand not controlling the throttles can operate them. It should also be possible to disengage the autopilot by manual operation of the control column. If disconnecting the autopilot via the ‘instinctive cut out’, the flight crew receives a short-term audio and visual warning.

content.question: Consider an aircraft established on an ILS with both autopilots engaged. When passing 35 feet of radio height, one of the IRS fails. What are the consequences?

options.A: The autopilot system will continue to operate normally, and the pilot will receive no warning or annunciation of the failed IRS.
options.B: The autopilot system will continue to operate normally, but the pilot will receive a message on the flight deck display indicating the failed IRS.
options.C: The autopilot system will automatically switch to the remaining IRS, and the pilot will receive a cautionary message indicating the failed IRS.
options.D: The autopilot system will disengage automatically, and the pilot will receive a warning or annunciation of the failed IRS.

key_points: The Fail-Operational Automatic Landing System A fail-operational automatic landing system is defined as the capability of a system to withstand a failure without affecting the overall functioning of the system and without causing degradation of performance beyond the limits required for an automatic landing
The system requires a minimum of three autopilots
Alert Height The alert height is a specified radio altimeter height, based on the characteristics of the aircraft and its fail operational landing system
learning.explanation: The Fail-Operational Automatic Landing System A fail-operational automatic landing system is defined as the capability of a system to withstand a failure without affecting the overall functioning of the system and without causing degradation of performance beyond the limits required for an automatic landing. The system requires a minimum of three autopilots. Alert Height The alert height is a specified radio altimeter height, based on the characteristics of the aircraft and its fail operational landing system. In operational use, if a failure occurred above the alert height in one of the required redundant operational systems in the aircraft, the approach would be discontinued, and a go-around executed unless reversion to a higher decision height is possible. If a failure in one of the required redundant operational systems occurred below the alert height, it would be ignored, and the approach would be continued to complete the autoland. If below the alert height all autopilots disengage, the ILS signal is lost, excessive ILS deviations occur, or the radio-altimeter fails, a warning will be triggered and an autoland procedure will not be possible.

content.question: An automatic ILS approach can be flown only…

options.A: within a range of crosswinds and no limit for turbulence.
options.B: without limits for crosswind or turbulence.
options.C: within a range of levels of turbulence and no limit for crosswinds.
options.D: within a range of crosswinds and levels of turbulence.

key_points: The purpose of an automatic landing system is to make the landing possible in poor weather conditions where visibility is highly degraded and is below CAT I minimas
The automatic landing will be achieved by using several onboard instruments: the radio altimeter, the autopilot, and the auto-throttle
The successful completion of an automatic landing depends on various items such as the crosswind, headwind, tailwind, runway contamination, etc
learning.explanation: The purpose of an automatic landing system is to make the landing possible in poor weather conditions where visibility is highly degraded and is below CAT I minimas. The automatic landing will be achieved by using several onboard instruments: the radio altimeter, the autopilot, and the auto-throttle. The successful completion of an automatic landing depends on various items such as the crosswind, headwind, tailwind, runway contamination, etc. that need to be within a certain range. Beyond the certified range of these variables, the automatic landing cannot be completed safely.

What steps characterize the FLARE mode during an autoland?
1. FMS mode freeze at 150 ft RA
2. Vertical speed reduction at 100 ft RA
3. Autothrust disengagement at 70 ft RA
4. At 50 ft RA, disengagement of Glide Slope mode and engagement of the FLARE mode

key_points: AUTOLAND Autoland describes a system that fully automates the landing phase of an aircraft's flight

The pilots assume a monitoring role during the final stages of the approach and will only intervene in the event of a system failure or emergency and, after landing, to taxi the aircraft off of the runway and to the parking location
FLARE MODE - Airbus Once the aircraft reaches approximately 40 ft RA (the precise value is a function of V/S): The FLARE mode engages
learning.explanation: AUTOLAND Autoland describes a system that fully automates the landing phase of an aircraft's flight. The pilots assume a monitoring role during the final stages of the approach and will only intervene in the event of a system failure or emergency and, after landing, to taxi the aircraft off of the runway and to the parking location. FLARE MODE - Airbus Once the aircraft reaches approximately 40 ft RA (the precise value is a function of V/S): The FLARE mode engages. The FMA displays “FLARE” in green. At 30 ft RA, the AP/FD aligns the yaw axis with the runway centreline and the aircraft flares on the pitch axis. If the autothrust is active, thrust is automatically reduced to IDLE. When both AP/FDs are disengaged, FLARE mode disengages. After main landing gear touchdown, the autopilot (if engaged) sends a nose down order. FLARE MODE - Boeing The A/P flare manoeuvre starts at approximately 50 feet RA and is completed at touchdown: FLARE engaged is annunciated and F/D command bars retract. the A/T begins retarding thrust at approximately 27 feet RA so as to reach idle at touchdown. A/T FMA annunciates RETARD. the A/T automatically disengages approximately 2 seconds after touchdown. the A/P must be manually disengaged after touchdown. Landing roll-out is executed manually after disengaging the A/P.

content.question: Whilst in straight and level flight with the autopilot engaged, the aircraft begins to pick up some autopilot-induced oscillations. Which of the following will happen if the pilot does not intervene?

options.A: Dutch roll.
options.B: Fuel starvation.
options.C: Unwanted pitch and/or roll.
options.D: Engine stall.

key_points: Note: This question is based on incomplete feedback, so may be slightly different than seen in the exam
Please put any further exam feedback you can remember in the comments or send by email to info@atplquestions
com, thank you very much
learning.explanation: Note: This question is based on incomplete feedback, so may be slightly different than seen in the exam. Please put any further exam feedback you can remember in the comments or send by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you very much. Pilot-induced oscillations are where the pilot "over-controls" the aircraft, and therefore, will not only correct for an incorrect attitude, altitude, speed, etc., but will over-correct, and go through the equilibrium, ending up in the opposite scenario. This can often be seen on a pilot's first few ILS approaches when they begin to get very accurate near the runway, or during the flare, when pilots sometimes over-flare, and end up porpoising (up and down) along the runway. It is very common in many stages of flight, and something to try and avoid. Autopilots can perform self-induced oscillations too, if they are not quick enough to catch the overcontrolling with their feedback loop, for example. This could be in pitch, or in yaw and roll (which could lead to Dutch roll). This question is very vague, it does not tell us what oscillations we are feeling, nor much about how they have been formed, so we have chosen the most vague answer that is correct (it could also be Dutch roll, but we would have to make a lot more assumptions, so we think that "Dutch roll" is not as correct).

key_points: The flight directors provide information for the pilot to join a desired path with the optimum attitude

Flying manually does not mean to fly without any helping tools
learning.explanation: The flight directors provide information for the pilot to join a desired path with the optimum attitude. Flight director information supplied by a FD computer is presented in the form of command bars on the Attitude Director Indicator (ADI). Flying manually does not mean to fly without any helping tools. In fact, the FDs are not only used when the AP is engaged but also when manually controlling the aircraft. Think about the last phase of the approach, most of the time you will leave the FDs ON after disconnecting the autopilot, and they will give you the optimum indications to remain on your glideslope and localizer beam until the touchdown.

content.question: A pilot is flying a CAT IIIA automatic approach, on an aeroplane equipped with a fail-passive automatic landing system, and intends to perform an autoland. After having acquired the required visual references, he/she notices that the FLARE did NOT engage at the expected height. If continuation of the approach is permitted, he/she can...

options.A: recycle automation and re-engage the autopilots to accomplish the automatic landing.
options.B: take control of the aeroplane and complete the landing manoeuvre manually.
options.C: announce the FMA failure and take control of the aeroplane after touchdown.
